Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Paleogenomic reconstruction and functional testing of archaic hominin olfactory receptors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The human sense of smell (olfaction) is central to many human activities and likely has a more complicated role in evolutionary pathways than previously suspected. Some examples of the important role olfaction plays in human behavior include detecting the fat content of food, directing food (and possibly mate) preference, and assessing health. Human olfaction is different from our closest living ape relatives, but it is not yet known if it is similar to or distinct from our extinct hominin relatives. The fundamental issue addressed by this project is whether or not genetic variation underlying odor detection receptors in the noses of modern humans, Neandertals, and Denisovans led to differences in how each species smelled the world. The investigators will use an innovative bioinformatics and laboratory approach to uncover rebuild key components of ancient noses. On a broad scale, the project promotes progress in the science of ancient genomes and evolutionary biology by assessing gene function in extinct populations. The data generated will contribute to human evolutionary genetics, biology, and anthropology. Application of these methods to other ancient genes has potential to transform our understanding of key evolutionary changes in humans, including genes implicated in human health and disease susceptibility. Finally, the project engages in public outreach to promote science education via a variety of national and international events, and includes funding to support training and professional development for under-represented individuals in STEM disciplines.

This EAGER project will investigate whether the olfactory repertoires of ancient hominins are distinct from or overlap with modern humans. Specifically, the investigators will determine if novel variants in the paleogenomes of Altai Neandertals and Denisovans resulted in distinct olfactory repertoires, using variant calling in the paleogenomes of these two hominins, reconstruction of 30 paleo-olfactory receptors via overlap extension polymerase chain reaction, and experimental validation of functional responses to odorants via a high throughput Dual-Glo Luciferase Assay System. The study will be one of the first to validate function of paleogenes and the first to do so on a large number of genes related to olfaction, an understudied area of human evolution. Identifying variation in olfactory repertoires within a comparative evolutionary framework may advance our understanding of hominin dietary evolution and evolutionary ecology. The investigators introduce a method that could be used by other researchers to validate function in other paleogenes that might shed light on modern human health problems, using paleospecies as a model (alongside others) for gene function.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. Interaction with the environment is mediated by the senses which have evolved filters to differentiate the critical elements of sensory umwelt (foods, mates, social signals, and dangers). Olfaction is an often overlooked signaling mechanism but one that is implicated in all aspects of human-environment interaction. The vast discriminatory power of the olfactory system requires higher-order neural processing to allow perception of individual odors—a small change to the molecular structure of an odorant results in a variety of odors and perceptions. In 1991 seminal paper on OR genes, Buck and Axel posed the question1: “How are the diversity and specificity of olfactory perception accomplished?” Over the last decade, a fluorescence in olfactory scientific discovery has advanced our knowledge on mammalian olfaction across domains. Despite these major discoveries, the question posed by Buck and Axel remains unanswered. This NSF project was to determine whether the genus Homo shared an olfactory repertoire and, by extension, environmental adaptation. To accomplish this goal, the first step was to scan genomic data for modern humans and ancient members of the genus (Neandertal, Denisova, Ust’-Ishim). This resulted in identification of variants unique to each species. Typically, the functional impact of variants is inferred based on what we know about living humans/primates when examining data generated via ancient DNA. We took a novel experimental approach to understand how these variants might have resulted in functional differences (e.g., if they resulted in different responses to odors) via creative application of gene expression assays. Simply put, we mutated human olfactory receptors to match paleogenomic sequences, cultured them in cells, and measured response to odors. This work offers an unprecedented opportunity to gain insights into the biology of species that became extinct hundreds of thousands of years ago. Our results of genetic analysis and functional testing suggest that members of the genus Homo share an olfactory repertoire but key differences exist in how novel variants across species affect the intensity of odorant responses.

Broader Impacts. Activities included public engagement activities, conference presentations, educational materials development, and undergraduate lab skills training. We conducted two major outreach events to the public; the first was a series of events in the UK as part of Being Human London 2015 (12-22 November), a festival organized and funded by the School of Advanced Study in partnership with the Arts & Humanities Research Council and the British Academy. We partnered with the UK charity Fifth Sense (devoted to aiding those who have lost their sense of smell and/or taste) and offered lectures, art-science exhibitions and interactive activities (e.g., smell walks, neurogastronomy). The second event was an interactive art-science show in Fairbanks Alaska that focused on the power of smell to alter perception of food/drink and virtually experience remote locations (through a series of phodorgraphs that paired odors evoking the essence of photographs of other places). Preliminary results of the award have been presented at various interdisciplinary science venues and garnered significant media interest (which resulted in several international pieces). The PIs integrated results of the research into their Higher Education Teaching Modules focused on the chemical senses. The project funded a female undergraduate student from an under-represented population to train in the various components of the lab work for functional testing.
